Deconstructing deception: Frequency, communicator
characteristics, and linguistic features of embeddedness
David M. Markowitz
Department of Communication, Michigan
State University, East Lansing, Michigan, USA

East Lansing, MI 48824, USA.

Abstract
Deceptive and truthful statements draw on a common pool of communication data,
and they are typically embedded within false and truthful narratives. How often does
embeddedness occur, who communicates embedded deceptions and truths, and
what linguistic characteristics reveal embeddedness? In this study, nearly 800 partici-
pants deceived or told the truth about their friends and indicated the embedded
deceptions (e.g., false statements told within entirely false or truthful messages) and
truths (e.g., truthful statements told within entirely false or truthful messages).
Embedded deceiving and truth-telling rates were only statistically different among
those who were instructed to tell the truth. Therefore, the distribution of embedded
deceptions and truths were similar for false statements, but dissimilar for truthful
statements. Embedded truths were also more likely to be written by women
(vs men), liberals (vs conservatives), and communicated in a formal versus narrative
style. Theoretical implications are discussed.
KEYWORDS
automated text analysis, deception, embedded deception, embeddedness, language, lying
1 | DECONSTRUCTING DECEPTION
1.1 | Frequency, communicator characteristics,
and linguistic features of embeddedness
Before giving sworn testimony, an oath officer typically asks a witness
the following question: “Do you swear to tell the truth, the whole
truth, and nothing but the truth, so help you God?” This famed state-
ment in the US judicial system holds witnesses to account by suggest-
ing that any deceptive information communicated during their
testimony can result in a charge of perjury. A critical issue exists with
the question at hand, however, because it assumes that one's state-
ment will be wholly and unequivocally truthful when communicated.
This assumption fails to reflect reality (e.g., lies are not completely
false, truths are not completely truthful), which undermines our ability
to describe the actual composition of lies and truths.
Prior work has addressed the idea of embeddedness (e.g., how
falsehoods are embedded within truths, how truths are embedded in
falsehoods) in several empirical studies and from different theoretical
perspectives (Amado et al.,
2016; Caso et al., 2023; Gnisci
et al., 2010; Leins et al., 2013; Levine, 2020; Luke, 2019;
Markowitz, 2020; McCornack et al., 2014; Nahari, 2018; Nahari &
Vrij, 2015; Sporer & Walther,2006; Strömwall & Willén,2011; Verigin
et al., 2019, 2020; Vrij, 2008; Vrij et al., 2007; Vrij, Granhag, &
Porter, 2010; Vrij & Mann,2001; Vrij, Mann, et al.,2010; Walczyk
et al., 2014). Specifically, embeddedness describes verbal behavior
where communicators, instead of telling a wholly truthful or untruth-
ful story, will“change specific vital details” in an otherwise truthful or
untruthful story (Vrij, Granhag, & Porter,2010, p. 94) Despite prior
work that has predominantly evaluated how embeddedness can be
revealed by details in a statement, outstanding and fundamental ques-
tions remain. Principally, what is the elemental composition of

deceptions and truths? The concept of embeddedness is advanced in
this paper by understanding the distribution of deceptions and truths
in false and truthful communication patterns, the antecedents of
embeddedness (e.g., who communicates embedded deceptions and
truths the most), and its defining linguistic characteristics (e.g., the
verbal features of embedded deceptions and truths). The next
section describes how the concept of embeddedness is rooted in
deception theory and how it has been examined empirically.
1.2 | Embedded deceptions: Support from
deception theory
The idea that deceptive and truthful messages are not completely
deceptive nor completely truthful is supported by Information Manip-
ulation Theory (McCornack,
1992). The theory presupposes that much
of deception research has rested on a bald-faced lie and bald-faced
truth dichotomy, which is inconsistent with how people actually tell
lies and truths (Bond & DePaulo,
2006; McCornack, 1997; Sporer &
Schwandt, 2007; Verigin et al.,2020). Instead, McCornack and col-
leagues argue that when people interact, they often abide by several
conversational rules that are inherently cooperative in nature
(Grice,
1989). These rules, called Grice's Maxims, are of great interest
to deception scholars when cooperationdoes not occur(Grice, 1975,
1989). That is, such covert violations of Gricean maxims of quantity
(e.g., the amount of information), quality (e.g., the truthfulness of the
information), manner (e.g., how the information is communicated), and
relation (e.g., the relevance of the information) constitute information
manipulation in various forms (Markowitz,
2020; McCornack, 1992;
McCornack et al., 2014). For example, as others indicate
(Levine, 2001), lying by omission violates the maxim of quantity, and
lying by equivocation violates the maxim of manner.
The issue with considering lies and truths as completely false or
completely truthful is that“by placing messages into global categories
(rather than construing them as existing at the intersection of multiple
dimensions) we necessarily lose information relevant to the subtle
message features that potentially influence deceptiveness ”
(McCornack,
1992, p. 11). Like a faucet that can run both warm and
cold water simultaneously (Markowitz, 2020), communication pat-
terns can contain both deceptive and truthful elements within the
same statement and draw on a common pool of communication data.
It is therefore critical to investigate if false statements indeed contain
a greater amount of false communication data than truthful communi-
cation data, and if truthful statements indeed contain a greater
amount of truthful communication data than false communication
data. Importantly, a goal of this piece is not to provide a definitive rate
or percentage of how much false and truthful information will be
within false and truthful messages across all communication acts,
prompts, or contexts. Instead, this piece aims to be a first step in test-
ing the validity of a more basic assumption about embeddedness in
deceptive communication: that false messages are more false than
truthful, and truthful messages are more truthful than false. This
assumption is examined empirically in the current study, along with an
exploratory examination of the social and psychological correlates of
embeddedness. A careful reader will also notice that prior work has
used the term embedded lies to describe false statements that are
embedded within entirely false or truthful messages. Here, the term
embedded deceptions is used, instead. This was purposeful, based on
definitions offered by Levine (
2014). Deception “is intentionally,
knowingly, or purposefully misleading another person,” whereas a lie
“is a subtype of deception that involves outright falsehood, which is
consciously known to be false by the teller, and is not signaled as false
to the message recipient” (Levine, 2014, p. 380). Based on the task in
this work, truth-tellers were unlikely to be tellingembedded lies, but
instead, they may have been tellingembedded deceptions.
Drawing on IMT and other theoretical perspectives, prior work
has investigated different dynamics related to embedded deceptions.
For example, recent research has typically considered how details are
a cue of embeddedness. Verigin et al. (
2020) had participants provide
an alibi for a fictional crime and those instructed to provide an entirely
truthful statement had more details than those instructed to provide
an entirely fabricated statement. However, lies embedded within
completely truthful statements did not have more details than lies
embedded within completely fabricated stories. Yet, other work has
observed that detailed information may be an important characteristic
of embedded deceptions during a mock crime (e.g., liars discussed
people they met, places they went) (Nahari et al.,
2014b). Embedded
deceptions and truths also occur interpersonally, as students who
gave feedback on their peers' artwork and disliked it tended to over-
state positive aspects of the work and understate negative aspects of
the work, suggesting such accounts were mostly truthful (Bell &
DePaulo,
1996). Further, a recent study by Caso et al. (2023) had
truth-tellers, outright liars, and embedders (e.g., people who were told
to tell the truth for half of a story and lie for the other half) communi-
cate to an interviewer about a memorable life event that happened in
the last 12 months. Embedders spent more time and put in more
effort to prepare their story for the interview than truth-tellers and
outright liars. However, the number of complications in embedders'
statements (e.g., details that make a person's story more complicated,
which are often found more often in truthful than deceptive speech;
Vrij et al.,
2021) was not significantly different than truth-tellers and
outright liars. Altogether, mixed evidence exists in term of the com-
municative signals of embeddedness across different deception set-
tings, yet the concept remains an important one to investigate for
frequency and social and psychological correlates.
While prior research has evaluated how details reveal the charac-
teristics of embedded deceptions/lies (Nahari et al.,
2014b; Verigin
et al., 2020), and when people may communicate embedded decep-
tions interpersonally (Bell & DePaulo,1996), few studies have evalu-
ated how often embeddedness generally occurs in false and truthful
statements. A related study found that people who assume fake iden-
tifies only adjust “a small portion” of their true identity (e.g., small
spelling variations of their true name) (Wang et al.,
2004, p. 123). It is
therefore crucial to identify the distribution of embedded deceptions
and truths in false and truthful communication because such informa-
tion can aid deception detectors, law enforcement, or other

statements. To build a deeper understanding of embeddedness, this
requires a basic description of how often and when this phenomenon
occurs.
Indeed, there is good reason to suspect that truth-tellers may
embed deceptions in their truthful statements. For example, if telling
an entirely truthful story is a problem (Levine,
2020), truth-tellers may
covertly deceive in the form of exaggerations (e.g., if writing about
one's feelings toward another person, overstating how they feel), eva-
sions (e.g., if writing about one's feelings toward another person,
dodging how they feel by writing abstractly), or equivocations (e.g., if
writing about one's feelings toward another person, being non-
committal or ambiguous about how they feel) (Levine,
2014). These
may be done for self-presentation or face-saving purposes (Bell &
DePaulo, 1996). The present work advances deception scholarship by
evaluating embeddedness holistically —particularly, how embedded
deceptions appear within entirely false and truthful statements, and
how embedded truths appear within entirely false and truthful
statements—examining the frequency and social and psychological
correlates of each. This leads to the first research question:
RQ1. To what degree are false statements comprised of
false and truthful communication patterns, and to what
degree are truthful statements comprised of false and
truthful communication patterns?
1.3 | Individual differences in deception research
Beyond distributions of embedded deceptions and truths, a critical
next step in this literature is the explication of who tends to systemat-
ically communicate embedded deceptions and truths. The current
work takes an individual differences approach to examine how dispo-
sitional antecedents and defining internal traits about an individual
relate to embeddedness.
Several individual differences are considered in the current paper
based on their connection to deception research at large. The first
interest focuses on aversive personality traits. Prior work suggests
those who are high on Machiavellianism (e.g., those who are manipu-
lative), high on narcissism (e.g., those who believe they are superior to
others and entitled), and high or psychopathy (e.g., those who are low
on empathy and high on thrill-seeking) tend to cheat more (Jones &
Paulhus,
2017) and self-report more deception, on average (Daiku
et al., 2021; Furnham et al., 2013; Halevy et al., 2014;
Markowitz, 2023b). With such dispositional characteristics that are
often connected to deception across settings (Jonason et al.,2014), it
is therefore important to consider how aversive personality traits are
also linked to embedded deceiving and embedded truth-telling, which
is an understudied empirical effort to date.
Alongside personality measures, demographic traits often link to a
variety of deception dynamics as well. On average, younger people
tend to lie more than older people (Levine et al.,
2013;
Markowitz, 2023b; Serota & Levine,2015), men tend to lie more than
women (Markowitz, 2023b; Serota & Levine,2015), and White indi-
viduals self-report telling fewer lies than people of other racial/ethnic
groups (Markowitz,
2023b; Serota et al., 2010). The relationship
between political ideology and deception is more mixed and lie-type
dependent, however. That is, Markowitz et al. ( 2023) suggested
people who are more conservative tend to self-report more big and
serious lies (Study 2), but the relationship between conservatism and
self-reported white lying was not statistically significant. Altogether,
prior evidence indicates that demographics often matter in predicting
deception rates and deception dynamics, which motivated their evalu-
ation in this work.
Relatedly, prior work suggests lying rates are not normally distrib-
uted, and certain individuals (self-reportedly) tell a disproportionate
number of lies in a population (Daiku et al.,
2021; Halevy et al.,2014;
Levine, 2014, 2020; Markowitz,2023b; Markowitz & Hancock,2018;
Serota et al.,2010, 2022, 2024; Serota & Levine,2015). Individuals
who engage in prolific lying (vs those who engage in everyday lying)
tend to be male, younger, and higher on aversive personality traits.
However, it is unclear if one's status as a person who engages in pro-
lific or everyday lying also indicates their rate of embedded deceiving
or embedded truth-telling. This open question is examined in the cur-
rent paper and represents another individual difference worth explor-
ing based on existing deception scholarship. The following research
question between individual differences and embeddedness states:
RQ2. What is the relationship between individual differ-
ences (e.g., aversive personality traits, demographics, one's
prolific lying tendency) and embedded deceiving and
embedded truth-telling?
1.4 | Verbal traces of embeddedness: A
psychology of language perspective
The final interest of this article—beyond evaluating distributions of
embedded deceptions and truths, and observing who tends to com-
municate embedded deceptions and truths—is an evaluation of how
embedded deceptions and truths are communicated linguistically.
The current work applies principles from the psychology of language
field to address this idea. Research in the psychology of language

the evidence suggests lies often contain fewer words, more negative
emotion, and fewer perceptual details than truths. It is important to
remember that the data underlying these effects typically originate
from studies evaluating bald-faced lies and bald-faced truths
(e.g., entirely false or entirely truthful, respectively), and not the
embedded components of a false or truthful statement
(McCornack,
1992; McCornack et al.,2014). A nontrivial advancement
of the current study, then, is the linguistic explication of embedded
deceptions and embedded truths to understand how they are commu-
nicated within false and truthful communication patterns.
Which language dimensions might matter to differentiate embed-
ded deceptions and embedded truths? Four language dimensions
were considered (and preregistered) in the current paper. The first
dimension is overall affect and emotion, specifically discrete positive
and negative emotions (happiness, anger, sadness, disgust, surprise,
fear), and positive and negative sentiment or tone (Barrett,
2017;
Barrett et al.,2007). Primary study and meta-analytic evidence sug-
gests lies often include more negative emotions than truths, perhaps
to reflect an increase in guilt, embarrassment, or psychological dis-
tancing during deception (Gino & Shea, 2012; Markowitz &
Griffin, 2020; Newman et al.,2003). Lies may also contain more posi-
tive emotions than truths to reflect the idea ofduping delight, where
people experience positive affect before or after telling a lie
(Ekman,
2001; Gunderson et al., 2022; ten Brinke & Porter,2012).
Given that emotion and affect are linked to deception in a range of
studies, the current work investigates how embeddedness is linked to
emotion and affect as well.
A second dimension of interest is self-references (e.g., words such
as I, me, myself), which consider the degree to which people focus
their attention on the self. Deception research often finds a system-
atic link between self-references and deception (Hauch et al.,
2015;
Markowitz & Griffin,2020; Newman et al.,2003), with lies containing
a lower rate of“I”-words than truths, possibly explained by a psycho-
logical distancing mechanism as well. Lies can be interpersonally prob-
lematic for people and communicating them can be stressful
(Ekman,
2001). This psychological experience can be revealed in the
language patterns of communicators through pronoun use and one's
reduced focus on their own thoughts, feelings, and actions. It is
unclear how one's self-focus is different across embedded deceptions
and truths, which is why it is currently investigated in the
current work.
Third, this work evaluated how one's communication style is
linked to deception through an analytic thinking index. Style words,
also known as function words, describehow one is communicating
(e.g., “how they put words together to create a message” and ways of
expressing oneself through function words) rather thanwhat one is
communicating about (e.g., the topic, Chung & Pennebaker,
2007,
p. 345; Pennebaker, 2011). Common style words include articles
(e.g., the, a), prepositions (e.g.,above, below), auxiliary verbs (e.g.,was,
were), and pronouns (e.g., me, they), and a recent paper suggests a
grouping of such word categories can approximate how people think
(Pennebaker et al., 2014). That is, prior work evaluated student
admissions essays to university and explored the linguistic features
most systematically related to grades at the end of college
(Pennebaker et al.,
2014). Students with higher grades used more arti-
cles and prepositions relative to storytelling words (e.g., pronouns,
conjunctions) compared to students with lower grades. The authors
concluded that these individuals were more complex and analytic
thinkers, and other work suggests people using high rates of such lan-
guage patterns tend to be higher on need for cognition than those
using low rates of such language patterns (Markowitz,
2023a). Indeed,
research finds that deceptive communication patterns tend to be writ-
ten in a less analytic manner (e.g., fewer articles and prepositions) rela-
tive to truthful communication patterns (Markowitz et al.,
2021;
Markowitz & Hancock,2016), suggesting linguistic style via an ana-
lytic thinking index is worth examining in association with
embeddedness.
Finally, deception research has a long history of evaluating the
rate of details across false and truthful statements (Johnson &
Raye, 1981; Markowitz & Hancock, 2014; Nahari, 2018; Nahari
et al.,2014b; Nahari et al.,2014a; Palena et al.,2021; Vrij,2008; Vrij,
Granhag, & Porter,2010). According to a recent meta-analysis, truth-
tellers report using more verifiable details in their statements than
liars (Palena et al.,
2021), but mixed primary study evidence exists in
terms of how details are embedded across false and truthful state-
ments. The rate of adjectives, which is one marker to approximate the
amount of detail in a text (Chung & Pennebaker,
2008; Markowitz &
Hancock, 2014), was examined in the current work. Together, the fol-
lowing research question is posed for the collection of preregistered
language dimensions.
RQ3. What is the relationship between language patterns
(i.e., affect, self-references, analytic thinking, adjectives)
and embedded deceptions and embedded truths?
1.5 | The current study
To address the prior research questions—and critically, to add to exist-
ing deception theory by articulating the distributions, communicator
characteristics, and linguistic features of embedded deceptions and
truths—a preregistered experiment was conducted using a large sam-
ple of online participants. People were randomly assigned to write
false or truthful opinions about their friends, and then participants
identified the embedded deceptions and truths within their text. Indi-
vidual differences were recruited, and automated text analyses were
performed on each participant's linguistic output, to assess who com-
municates embedded deceptions and truths, and the linguistic associ-
ations with embeddedness, respectively.
This work is timely and important because the explication of sev-
eral features of embedded deceptions and truths are missing from the
deception literature (e.g., their rate, who tends to communicate them
most often, and how they are communicated verbally), but they
remain theoretically necessary to deepen the concept of embedded-
ness in the field. Existing deception theory (e.g., IMT) and other

2 | METHOD
2.1 | Participants and power
An a priori power analysis estimating a small effect at 80%
power (Cohen's d = 0.20, α = .05, two-tailed) suggested 788 partici-
pants were required in this two-condition study. This power estimate
originates from meta-analytic evidence that suggests, on average, the
relationship between deception and language patterns yields small
but reliable effects (Hauch et al.,
2015).
A total of 800 US participants were recruited from Prolific and
received $4.25 for their participation. Ten participants were excluded
for providing nonsensical responses (finalN = 790). Most participants
self-identified as women (n = 398, 50.4%; menn = 377, 47.7%; other
n = 14, 1.8%) and were 38.64 years old, on average
(SD = 13.05 years). Most participants also self-identified as White
(n = 581, 73.5%), with other race/ethnicities less represented in the
sample. The sample and procedure were preregistered,

2.2 | Procedure
Following the procedure outlined in prior deception studies that has
reliably solicited false or truthful statements from participants
(DePaulo & Rosenthal,
1979; Markowitz & Griffin, 2020; Newman
et al., 2003), people were randomly assigned to lie or tell the truth
about their friends. Participants wrote for a total of 5 minutes and
after this time, the survey platform automatically progressed, which
intentionally created a consistent writing experience across partici-
pants. Those randomized to the truthful condition were given instruc-
tions that stated:
Your task is to write about your friends. We want you
to talk about two friends that you like and two friends
that you do not like. It is important that you tell us your
truthful and honest views, as people may attempt to
guess your true views.
Those randomized to the deceptive condition were
given instructions that stated:
Your task is to write about your friends. We want you
to talk about two friends that you like and two friends
that you do not like. However, we would like you to
talk about the people you like as if you do NOT like
them and talk about the people you do not as if you
liked them.
After the writing task, participants were told“Research suggests
there may be both truthful and deceptive parts of a message. In other
words, a message may not be fully truthful or fully deceptive” and
they were instructed to indicate the parts of their text that were
deceptive and truthful. Participants were instructed to read left to
right, and then copy and paste words, phrases, or sentences that were
deceptive or truthful into a maximum of 20 text boxes. The order of
this task (e.g., copying and pasting deceptive or truthful parts of each
message) was randomized. Crucially, for proper grounding and consis-
tent interpretation of dishonesty, participants were provided with a
commonly accepted definition of deception from the literature (“a
text that is intentionally false or misleading ”) (Levine,
2014;
Vrij, 2008).
Three specific instructions for the copying and pasting process
were given. Verbatim, these instructions stated: (1) You will go
through your text, copying and pasting the phrases or full sentences
that were either deceptive or truthful (depending on the instruc-
tions). You will do this for up to 20 pieces of text. (2) If you have
multiple deceptions or truths in one sentence, please place them on
different lines (different text boxes). (3) After you copy and paste a
piece of text, you will rate each statement on a scale of (1) Not at all
deceptive (or truthful) to (5) Extremely deceptive (or truthful). To
ensure participants copied and pasted texts correctly, an example of
this process was provided (see the online supplement out of space
considerations). Alongside each text that was copied and pasted,
participants rated the deceptiveness or truthfulness of each state-
ment on a 5-point scale (1 = Not at all [truthful/deceptive] to
5 = Extremely [truthful/deceptive]) that was derived from prior
work (Markowitz & Hancock,
2018). High scores were intended to
be high ratings of deceptiveness and therefore, all ratings on the
truthful scale were reverse-scored.
2.3 | Measures
2.3.1 | Embedded deceiving and truth-telling rates
An embedded deceiving rate and embedded truth-telling rate were
created by identifying the number of statements that participants
copied and pasted in their evaluation of embedded deceptions and
truths, and dividing this number by 20 (i.e., the total number of text
boxes provided).
i Therefore, each person received two embeddedness
rates, the main dependent variables of this work. An example of how
the embeddedness rates were calculated, using an excerpt from a par-
ticipant's writing, is in the online supplement out of space
considerations.

2.3.2 | Self-reported lying frequency and prolific
lying identification
Participants were asked to indicate the number of white lies and big
lies that they tell each day using items from prior work
(Markowitz,
2023b; Serota & Levine, 2015). Two questions asked,
“On average, how many times a day do you tell a [little white/big]
lie?” with 10 scale points: 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 10, 15, 20, 25+. All 25+
responses were recoded as 25.
Recall, prior work suggests participants can be categorized into
those who engage in prolific lying and those who engage in everyday
lying by analyzing their self-reported lying rates (Markowitz,
2023b;
Serota & Levine,2015). This is accomplished statistically by creating
an index of dispersion, which is calculated by dividing the variance of
the measure by the mean of that same measure, removing cases at
the right-hand tail of a distribution until the value approximates 1.0
(D;≈1). That is, whenD≈1, this is the pivot point at which two sub-
samples are created (e.g., separating those who engage in prolific lying
on the right-hand tail from those who engage in everyday lying). Peo-
ple who engaged in prolific white lying self-reported telling more than
5 white lies (D = 1.09) and people who engaged in prolific big lying
self-reported telling more than 2 big lies (D = 1.07). In contrast, those
who engaged in everyday white lying reported telling 5 or fewer white
lies and those who engaged in everyday big lying reported telling 2 or
fewer big lies. This process occurred to identify if the rate and charac-
teristics of embedded deceptions and truths differed by those who
engaged in prolific lying.
2.3.3 | The dark triad
Three aversive personality traits, known as The Dark Triad, were mea-
sured using a 27-item scale from prior work (Jones & Paulhus,
2014).
The subscales of Machiavellianism (Cronbach'sα = 0.79), narcissism
(Cronbach's α = 0.82), and psychopathy (Cronbach'sα = 0.75) were
highly reliable. Please see the online supplement for sample items out
of space considerations.
2.3.4 | Demographics
Age, gender (3 levels: man, woman, other), race/ethnicity (6 levels:
White, Black/African American, Asian, American Indian, Native
Hawaiian, Other), and a 7-point measure of political ideology were
assessed (1= extremely liberal, 7= extremely conservative).
2.4 | Automated text analysis
The automated text analysis tool, Linguistic Inquiry and Word Count
(LIWC: Pennebaker et al., 2022), evaluated all texts in this study.
LIWC counts words as a percentage of the total word count per text.
For example, the statement“I dislike my friend” contains four words,
and LIWC counts several words within its internal dictionary of social
(e.g., words related to friends), psychological (e.g., words related to
emotion, cognition), and part of speech dimensions (e.g., articles, pro-
nouns). From the prior statement, LIWC identified self-references
(e.g., I, my; 50% of the total word count), negative emotion terms
(e.g., dislike; 25% of the total word count), and friends-related words
(25% of the total word count), and this process was repeated for
each text.
As noted, four verbal dimensions were used to evaluate the lin-
guistic differences between embedded deceptions and truths:
(1) affect, which is a global category that includes positive and
negative emotions (e.g., words such as happy, sad), plus positive
and negative sentiment/tone (e.g., words such as birthday, coffin),
(2) self-references (e.g., “I” words), which indicate a person's self-focus
and attention (3) the rate ofanalytic thinking, which indicates a per-
son's formal and complex thinking style (Jordan et al.,
2019;
Markowitz, 2023a; Pennebaker et al.,2014),ii and (4)adjectives, which
indicate the descriptiveness of one's verbal output (Chung &
Pennebaker,
2008). Prior evidence suggests these language dimen-
sions are often related to deception (e.g., Hauch et al., 2015;
Johnson & Raye, 1981; Markowitz & Hancock,2014, 2016; Verigin
et al.,2020), which motivated their inclusion in the current article.

3.7 | Exploratory results
Perhaps one surprising result is the amount of overlap between
embedded deceptions and embedded truths across conditions (results
addressing RQ1). It is therefore important to investigate the source of
this overlap at the language level to possibly describe why these dif-
ferences (or lack thereof) occurred.
To accomplish this aim, embedded deceptions and embedded
truths were independently submitted to the Meaning Extraction
Method for each condition (Chung & Pennebaker, 2008;
Markowitz, 2021). This technique uses Principal Component Analysis
to identify how content words cluster statistically after varimax rota-
tion. The approach, which first removes style words (e.g., articles,
prepositions, pronouns) and low base-rate words to prepare for the
analysis of content words, has received robust support in communica-
tion research and psychology as a way to systematically evaluate
themes and topics from large text collections (Blackburn et al.,
2018;
Chung & Pennebaker, 2008; Fauville et al., 2023; Markowitz &
Slovic, 2020; Pham et al., 2023; Ramirez-esparza et al., 2008;
Rubaltelli et al., 2023). Consistent with prior work (Foxman
et al., 2021; Markowitz, 2021), the number of extracted themes was
determined by a combination of scree plot evidence, variance
explained (e.g., each additional theme should contribute a nontrivial
amount of added variance), and thematic interpretability. Words
retained in each analysis were unigrams (single words), and they must
have appeared in at least 5% of all texts per corpus to be considered
for meaning extraction.

4 | DISCUSSION
The current study evaluated an understudied question in deception
research: How much of truthful messages are indeed truthful
(or deceptive), and how much of deceptive messages are indeed
deceptive (or truthful)? Upon writing false or truthful opinions about
their friends, participants reflected on their messages for embedded
deceptions and truths. The rate of embedded deceiving and truth-
telling were not statistically different among those who wrote false
statements about their friends, but among those who wrote truthful
statements about their friends, they reported more embedded truths
than deceptions (addressing
RQ1). This is some of the first evidence of
its kind to reveal the compositional elements of false and truthful
communication patterns. In addition to evaluating rates of embedded
deceptions and truths, this work considered who communicates
embedded deceptions and truths (addressing
RQ2) and the linguistic
characteristics of embeddedness (addressingRQ3). Embedded truths
were often written by women and liberals, suggesting individual dif-
ferences linked to embeddedness. Embedded truths were also written
in a more formal and analytical manner than embedded deceptions.
This study adds to our basic theoretical understanding of decep-
tion production in several ways. First, to date, assumptions about the
distributions of embeddedness within false and truthful messages
have largely been untested. Now, the current work suggests that rates
of embedded deceptions and truths are different among truthful mes-
sages, but not false messages. Therefore, not only is the bald-faced lie
and bald-faced truth dichotomy largely inaccurate for deception
research (McCornack,
1992; McCornack et al., 2014; Verigin
et al., 2020), but rates of embeddedness are also a function of mes-
sage type (e.g., false messages will not universally have more embed-
ded deceptions than truths). This result has critical implications for the
study of deception because it suggests deceptions and truths are
indeed comprised of false and truthful communication data, but only
truthful messages show enough separability between the number of
embedded deceptions and truths that are within each text. This result
affirms critical assumptions of many deception theories
(e.g., deceptions and truths draw on a common pool of communica-
tion data; Markowitz,
2020; McCornack et al., 2014; Walczyk
et al.,2014), putting actual data to theoretical ideas. Together, it may
be methodologically convenient to consider lies and truths as
completely deceptive or truthful, but this work suggests the communi-
cation of veracity is more nuanced and layered.
It is important to recall that this piece did not aim to provide a
universal rate of embedded deceptions and truths that would occur
within any false or truthful message. Instead, it aimed to suggest a
possible distribution of embedded deceptions and truths in such mes-
sage types. With other prompts, settings, writing topics, and calcula-
tions of embeddedness, absolute rates of embedded deceptions and
truths will indeed change. However, this work is critical because it
indicates how embeddedness differences are a function of veracity.
Future work should seek to replicate these ideas without explicit
veracity prompting as well.
A critical follow-up question to the present results asks: Why did
truth-tellers include embedded deceptions? While a definitive answer
to this question is unobtainable, the automated thematic extraction
results suggested that these deceptions were quite broad, non-
specific, and abstract compared to embedded truths. There are several
possible reasons for deceptions to appear within truthful statements.
First, as noted, truth-tellers may embed deceptions in the form of
exaggerations, evasions, or equivocations, particularly for
self-presentation purposes (e.g., participants may have deceived by
exaggerating how great of friends they have, presumably to appear
likeable) or for face-saving purposes (e.g., participants may have
deceived by equivocating about why they dislike certain people)
(Bell & DePaulo,
1996). Unfortunately, the present data do not allow
for an analysis to understand the precise motivations behind embed-
ded deceiving or truth-telling, despite the finding that suggests they
have a different linguistic signature in terms of content. However, as
others suggests (DePaulo,
1992; Levine, 2019), the reasons for lying
and truth-telling may often be similar (e.g., people often want to make
a favorable impression when lyingand truth-telling), suggesting it is an
opportunity for future work to examine if motivations are differential
across embeddedness, and under which settings or conditions are
embedded deceptions told at various rates.

writing tasks and certain samples, that embeddedness rates are

among those who are telling the truth, requiring scholars to rethink
how deception production (e.g., how false and truthful statements are
comprised of false and truthful elements) and deception detection
research inform each other (e.g., when to look for differences in rates
of false and truthful communication among suspected false and truth-

tices during interrogations, including the types of verbal traces that
identify embedded deceptions or embedded truths. Having law
enforcement and other institutions take language patterns seriously,
including one's own linguistic style to indicate embeddedness, is an
outcome that can possibly be implemented in real-time with natural
language processing techniques.
Second, by indicating personal characteristics of those who tell
embedded deceptions and truths, this work further deepens an argu-
ment that individual differences matter in deception research and link
to dynamics like embeddedness. While many demographic traits
linked to embeddedness (e.g., gender, political ideology), aversive per-
sonality traits did not. That narcissism, Machiavellianism, and psy-
chopathy linked to self-reported lying rates in expected ways
(Table

null effects are unlikely related to measurement issues. Instead,
embeddedness may be linked to some individual differences
(e.g., demographics) and prolific lying, but not others (e.g., personality).
Third, by examining how embeddedness was associated with lan-
guage, the current study explicates how embedded deceptions and
truths are constructed verbally. There are several points worth under-
scoring about the relationship between embeddedness and language.
First, the null finding between adjectives and embeddedness repli-
cates a prior study that found lies embedded within complete truths
were not more detailed than lies within complete falsehoods (Verigin
et al.,
2020). On average, truths tend to have more verifiable details
than lies (Palena et al.,2021), but mixed evidence exists in terms of
embeddedness. These non-uniform and often conflicting findings
require that future work continues to examine the relationship
between verbal communication (e.g., adjectives) and embedded
deceiving. A second point worthy of explication relates to the system-
atic relationship between analytic thinking and embeddedness. This
study observed that embedded truths were more analytical and for-
mal than embedded deceptions (e.g., more articles and prepositions
relative to storytelling words like pronouns), a pattern generally con-
sistent with deception literature that has considered complete truths
and complete lies (Markowitz et al.,
2021; Markowitz &
Hancock, 2016). It appears that some language dimensions are linked
to veracity at complete and embedded levels of analysis, an idea that
should also be explored with more verbal dimensions.
Finally, it is worth commenting on the results offered in Table2.
A critical reader might suggest that the amount of overlap across
deceptive and truthful embedded messages is curious. Considering
the typical effect sizes in deception and language studies—plus, the
support from IMT, which argues that lies and truths draw from a com-
mon source of linguistic information—these differences are indeed
reasonable. Recall, Hauch et al. (
2015) observed that there are small,
yet reliable associations between deception and language. Effect size
differences between conditions in this study (Table
2) are consistent
with this meta-analytic summary. Therefore, the amount of overlap
between embedded deceptions and truths across conditions is consis-
tent with expectations from theory and prior work on the linguistic
traces of deception, yet predominantly revealed by those who were
instructed to tell the truth. The source of this overlap, as revealed in
the exploratory thematic analyses, is also at least partially explained
by topical similarities and differences across embedded deceptions
and truths. Since participants were asked to write about the same
general topic (i.e., their friends), it is reasonable that they would report
some similar themes among sanctioned deceptions (e.g., negative
experiences with a friend, how two people met). Yet, there were criti-
cal differences that betrayed embedded deceptions and truths among
those who were told to tell the truth. Future work would benefit from
further exploring the linguistic similarities and differences across
embedded deceptions and truths to identify more nuance in the pool
of information that people draw on for their communication output.
The remainder of a person's language patterns—aside from embedded
deceptions and truths among false and truthful statements—is also
worth investigating.
4.1 | Limitations and future directions
The current work only had participants provide one piece of writing
using a relatively benign topic. As one of the first studies to evaluate
rates of embeddedness, characteristics of communicators related to
embeddedness, and linguistic traits of embeddedness, using a vali-
dated writing exercise from prior work was intentional (DePaulo &
Rosenthal,
1979; Markowitz & Griffin,2020; Newman et al.,2003).
Plus, this study attempted to keep the effort burden low for partici-
pants and within funding limitations, which constrained the amount of
writing time and topics that could be addressed in the work. There-
fore, obtaining multiple writing samples across a diversity of topics—
and if using the friends prompt in the future, dividing the prompt into
two separate tasks or experimental conditions: (a) write about some-
one you dislike as if you liked them vs. (b) write about someone you
like as if you do not—would benefit this line of work and help to
assess the generalizability of the findings. For example, if people were
told to discuss alleged activities instead of opinions, the pattern of
results may be less clear. This is an open empirical question that
should be addressed in future research.
Another limitation is that, like most deception studies
(Levine,
2018), participants were instructed to lie or tell the truth
(e.g., sanctioned lying), which might deviate from their normal or
everyday behavior. Sanctioned lying is often a constraint of deception
research, which does not take away from the current empirical pack-
age nor its findings, but still requires acknowledgement. Future work
could collect observational data (e.g., text messages) and have

While prior deception research was used as a foundation to con-

and language dimensions of interest in the current work, there are
others that may warrant inclusion in the future. For example, prior
work suggests people are often opportunistic cheaters and deceivers
(Ariely,
2012; Kouchaki & Smith,2014; Markowitz & Levine,2021).
People deceive when the truth is a problem and when an opportunity
for deception is present with something to gain (Ariely,
2012;
Levine, 2020; Markowitz & Levine,2021). It may be helpful to exam-
ine if one's tendency to behave deceptively on one-off tasks is predic-
tive of embedded deceiving or truth-telling, or if a person's embedded
deceiving (or truth-telling) rate in one setting is associated with their
embedded deceiving (or truth-telling) rate in another setting (or, as
others like Serota et al.,

consistent over time). The contextual similarities and constraints of a
deception setting are also worth investigating as they relate to
embedded deceiving (Markowitz et al., 2023; Markowitz &
Hancock, 2019), since prior work suggests that elements ofthe con-
text (e.g., psychological dynamics, pragmatic goals, genre conventions,
dispositional factors, situational factors, interpersonal factors) can
shape how deception affects language. Altogether, while this current
work has pushed the concept of embeddedness forward in new ways,
future research would benefit from taking this idea more seriously in
the deception literature to understand its social, psychological, and
cultural antecedents and consequences.
Finally, when participants indicated their embedded deceptions,
they did not rate the severity of such messages (e.g., as a little white
lie or a big lie) beyond a simple Likert-type scale rating of deceptive-
ness. Future work might have participants rate embedded deceptions
for lie type severity to understand how different lie types are commu-
nicated and with various linguistic characteristics. Asking participants
to report their self-estimated percentages of truth telling and lying
may also provide additional information to understand how embedd-
edness is a clear or conscious concept for people to report in decep-
tion studies.
